PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional distrubances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivating and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dingoes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This Petition of concerned people, believes the Dingo, Australia's Native Dog, is an integral part of our wildlife and national heritage, and deserving of our conservation and humanity.
1. That the Dingo be removed from the classification of 'noxious', or vermin throughout Australia.
2. That the Dingo be given the same measure of protection as other wildlife, or breeds of dog, and that the persecution, and destruction of the Dingo as a breed be stopped, and outlawed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

As honourable senators will see, the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority interim annual report is marked with an asterisk on the circulated list. There are a few things that I would like to say about this report and about the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. As the previous Minister for Education-Minister for part of the period covered by this report-it was a pleasure for me to be associated with the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and with its operation. It was a particular pleasure to be able to work with the Chairman of the Authority, Dr Campbell, and with the Chief Education Officer, Dr Hancock, from both of whom I received the most positive and loyal assistance. I found it quite distressing last year when those officers and members of the Authority, when considering certain difficult problems, made recommendations to me which were then reported in the Press in such a way as to bring into some question either the competence or the dedication of those officers and of the Authority. I should like to place on record my belief that the Authority worked on all the difficult matters-I will mention one of them in a moment-in a way which I think would bring credit upon all officers in the Public Service, and certainly upon the Authority they served.

The issue which caused most controversy last year was that concerning the rationalisation of schools in north Canberra, an area in which the population of school aged children diminished while it was increasing in other parts of the Australian Capital Territory. The matter for the Authority to work out was whether one or several schools needed to be closed or in some other way phased down. The Authority had a very difficult task. There was pressure from the community to keep all the community schools running. The Authority, on the other hand, had to make decisions which were fair to all citizens of the Australian Capital Territory and which were educationally sound. In the event, the Authority recommended that Watson High School should be phased out, and I accepted that recommendation. Just before the election I was examining an alternative proposal that the present cohort of students from years 7, 8 and 9 should be allowed to finish their time at Watson High before it finally closed.

In any event, the decision has now been taken that Watson High School will remain open. That is fine; that is a new recommendation from the Authority and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has accepted it. But the retention of a smaller Watson High School will be an expensive option. If this is the course to be followed the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority will require extra resources. Without those extra resources children and parents somewhere else in the Australian Capital Territory system will have to yield resources. They will have to receive less to take up what is a fairly expensive option of keeping Watson High School open. It is incumbent upon Senator Ryan, as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, to indicate clearly and quickly that she will provide extra real resources to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. If she fails to do that it follows that somewhere else in the system resources will have to be diminished in order to keep Watson High School open. I hope the Minister will come forward with this information and with this assurance.

Two things in this report should be mentioned. This is an interim annual report because the Authority has had some difficulty with the Department of Finance in working out an appropriate means of presenting the accounts. Honourable senators will, I think, indicate their approval of the action taken by the Authority. As it has not yet been able to get agreement from the Department of Finance, or the process is still continuing, it has produced an interim report pending the resolution of its arguments as to what is an appropriate accounting method. The only difficulty it has had is that because it operates in a very special circumstance some of the accounting methods available were not appropriate.

The only other thing to say is that the attendance records shown in this report indicate that three members of the Authority had outstandingly poor attendance records for 1981-82. They were Mr Lee, Mr White and Ms Connors. They each attended only six meetings of the Authority. One of these people has now become a full time member of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I hope her attendance record there will be appropriate. The other two were school principals, one at Woden Valley High School and one, I think, at Hawker College. It was an indication that neither of them could really attend the Authority meetings as often as is appropriate. It just highlights the need to have community members who can commit time to the Authority and it gives us the warning that some of the people who attended ex officio or as principals of other schools may not have had the time required to do what is a very exacting job.

I think it would be agreed by all members of parliament that this Committee could well have far reaching effects on the electoral processes in this country. It would therefore be agreed that all parliamentarians would have a vital interest in the work of the Committee, in any recommendations which emerge from the Committee's considerations and in the final outcome of those recommendations. SPEECH.PARA: When such a committee was first considered by the Senate-it was the year before last, from memory-I was one of those who suggested that it ought not be merely a Senate committee because it would be considering issues which were of vital interest to members of the House of Representatives. At that stage it was agreed that the committee should be a joint committee and accordingly the Senate passed a motion to that effect. In the event, the Government of the day did not consider the establishment of the committee to be appropriate and therefore the House of Representatives did not agree to the establishment of a joint committee .

The resolution which was adopted by the House of Representatives was transmitted to the Senate yesterday. There was debate on it yesterday afternoon. That resolution, on the face of it, provides for a wide spread of opinion to be put to that Committee. In other words, it provides for membership by the Government party, by the Liberal Party and by the National Party of Australia and also for a member from the minority, an independent senator or senators.

Yesterday I was rather surprised that the Opposition sought an amendment, not to include me but to include a National Party senator. Of course, the opinions of the National Party are already catered for by reason of the resolution which was adopted by the House of Representatives. That amendment was put forward without any consultation; nor should consultation necessarily have taken place. In the event, the resolution was adopted. I then proceeded to make contact with the Australian Democrats, the presumed minority party that is mentioned in the resolution. In accordance with the spirit of Standing Order 36AA I sought to obtain an understanding as to who would go onto the Committee. I found that already a nomination had been made. But nevertheless, I believe that the Australian Democrats and other members of parliament desire to ensure that all opinions are able to be expressed and that there should be a participation by those representing those opinions at the deliberative stage of the Committee.

The question arises as to how that can be done. I presume it would be rather awkward for one member of the Australian Democrats to serve for half of the time , three-quarters of the time or five-sixths of the time and then for me to serve the extra one-fifth of the time. I suppose that half a loaf is better than none. I therefore accept the situation although it is not the optimum situation.

This Bill is part of the unfinished taxation legislation of the former Government and is one of the measures which the Minister for Finance announced on 30 March 1983 would be proceeded with by this Government in these sittings. The Bill will provide legislative authority for the Commissioner of Taxation to pay interest on certain refunds of tax made as a result of a successful objection or appeal by a taxpayer against an assessment or other specified decision of the Commissioner. Interest is to be payable in respect of those taxes which are, under existing law, exposed to an additional (penalty) tax of 20 per cent per annum, if they are not paid by the due date for payment. Taxes in this category are income tax (including provisional tax) ascertained by assessment or similar procedure, recoupment tax payable under the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act and the bank account debits tax.

The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act (No. 6) 1982 which was passed last year with the support of the Labor Party increased with effect from 14 February 1983 the rate of penalty tax for late payment of income tax and related amounts. The rise was from 10 per cent per annum to 20 per cent per annum. The Act also restricted the power of the Commissioner of Taxation to remit that penalty tax to cases involving specified or special circumstances. These amendments mean that disputed income tax will have to be paid by the due date or run the risk of additional penalty tax at the rate of 20 per cent per annum. Similarly, under legislation establishing liability to recoupment tax and bank account debits tax , any amounts not paid by the due date for payment will, subject to remission in specified or special circumstances, incur additional penalty tax at the rate of 20 per cent per annum.

This Government supports the concept, as we did in opposition, that interest should be paid where tax is refunded to a taxpayer as a result of a successful objection or appeal against an assessment or other decision of the Commissioner. This Bill will achieve that aim. Interest will also be payable where tax is, instead of being refunded to a taxpayer, applied by the Commissioner of Taxation against any other tax liability. Honourable senators will note that the rate at which interest is to be calculated is initially to be set in the Bill at 14.026 per cent per annum. This rate is the weighted average of yields of the longest term Treasury bonds contracted for in the most recent Treasury bond tender, the results of which were announced on 19 April 1983. The Bill provides that subsequent variations in the rate of interest to reflect changes in the benchmark rate are to be made by regulation. Interest will accrue for the period during which tax was, by reason of the decision on the objection or appeal, found to have been overpaid. Typically, this will mean that interest will accrue from the later of the date on which the tax was paid, or the date of the disputed assessment or other decision, to the date the overpaid amount is refunded to, or applied against another tax liability of, the taxpayer. Interest will not accrue however in respect of periods before 14 February 1983, which is the date on which the increased rate of 20 per cent per annum for late payment of income tax commenced to apply.

The Bill provides that interest is not to be paid to taxpayers who, in accordance with administrative procedures commonly known as the '50/50 rule' in operation prior to the commencement of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act ( No. 6) 1982 on 13 December 1982, made an arrangement with the Commissioner of Taxation for the remission of additional penalty tax accruing in respect of part of outstanding income tax pending resolution of a dispute, provided the remaining tax was paid. I mention that, as was indicated by the previous Government last year, interest paid on overpaid tax will form part of the assessable income of the recipient in the year of receipt and be subject to income tax. An explanatory memorandum providing detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill is being made available to honourable senators and I do not think it necessary to say more at this stage.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill was first introduced into the Senate on 11 November 1981. After a long and lively debate, in the course of which a number of amendments were made to the original Bill, it was passed by the Senate on 17 November 1982. It is the most important of the four proposals that are now to be put to referendum. The present Bill is the same as the 1982 Bill except for the incorporation of a convention relating to section 13, which was unanimously approved by the Adelaide meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention, and some drafting changes. The section 13 matter concerns the division of senators into 'short-term' and 'long-term' senators after a double dissolution and I shall deal with it later. Since the Bill was passed by the Senate we have had yet another example of an early election-that of March 1983-and now we learn that the British Parliament is to go to the polls 11 months ahead of the due date, ending a lengthy period of speculation about the date of its election.

While the Bill may appear at first sight very complex, its basic content is quite simple. The basic fixed term rule is that elections for the House of Representatives are to be held on a constitutionally fixed date-namely the third Saturday in November every three years-which cannot be varied at the discretion of the Prime Minister or Government of the day. This basic rule is subject to two qualifications: An early House of Representatives election can be held in the event that the Government of the day loses a no-confidence vote in the lower House and no alternative government can be formed; and double dissolutions can occur, as at present, in the event of a prolonged deadlock between the House and Senate. But in either case the incoming Government does not commence a new three -year term, rather it merely serves out the term of its predecessor, ensuring that the basic three-year cycle is quickly restored.

Although opposed by the previous Government at all stages, the Bill in its final form received very substantial cross-party support, with the Australian Labor Party being joined at the third reading not only by the five Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, but also by six Liberal senators. The Bill has also had at all stages strong and consistent support in newspaper editorials, and from the nation's most prominent and respected public affairs commentators. The reasons why the Bill has received such support are not hard to identify. Essentially, it has been seen as a moderate and constructive attempt to solve-or at least go a long way towards solving-two quite fundamental kinds of constitutional problems that have become apparent in recent years, and to do so in a way that is in the long term interests of all sides of politics and of the community as a whole.
Problems Addressed by the Bill

The first problem addressed by the Bill is the utter lack of stability and predictability in the Australian electoral cycle. The present constitutional rules allow the Prime Minister of the day to call an election for the House of Representatives more or less at whim, and moreover, to demand a double dissolution more or less at whim in the event that the formal precondition of a deadlock with the Senate over some matter has been established. In recent decades, early elections have become the rule rather than the exception. Since the Second World War, the average life of the House of Representatives has been not three years, but two years and four months. Cynicism and opportunism have become the order of the day. Acute uncertainty constantly reigns, often beginning very early in the life of a parliament, as to how long the parliament will last. Rational planning, in both the public and the private sector, becomes difficult to the point of impossibility, with ad hoc decision making being the norm, and short term political advantage the yardstick against which policy is formulated and implemented. Bad enough in good times, this spells disaster in times-like the present-of economic crisis. If accepted at referendum the Bill will obviously do a great deal to restore predictability, stability and sanity to the political system.

The second basic problem to which the Bill is addressed is the instability of our democratic political system flowing not from the Prime Minister's power to pick an election date of his own choosing, but from the existence and use of the Senate's power to force a government to the polls by blocking Supply in a situation where that Government retains its majority in the lower House, that is the problem of 11 November 1975.

The 1975 constitutional crisis was undoubtedly one of the most traumatic events in Australia's political history, with the community deeply divided-not always on strict party lines-as to the legitimacy of what occurred. A legacy of bitterness was created by the actions of the Senate and the intervention of the Governor-General which still shows little sign of dissipation. Perhaps even more importantly, an institutional legacy was also clearly established by the events of 1974 and 1975, such that no government lacking a secure majority in the Senate can any longer look forward to seeing out its full term. If an opposition sees it as politically advantageous to use them, the weapons are ready to hand every six months with the recurring Supply and Appropriation Bills. The potential for instability inherent in the letter of the Australian Constitution has at last been fully realised.

Since 1975 nothing has changed. The constitution has not been amended in any relevant respect. It remains within the power of the Senate to block Supply and, in these circumstances, within the power of the Governor-General to dismiss governments retaining the confidence of the House of Representatives and to dissolve the parliament. There are various ways of tackling the problem posed by the 1975 precedent which, until resolved, will continue to haunt both sides of politics. The two most direct, and extreme solutions are those which have been championed respectively by Mr Whitlam on behalf of the ALP and Sir Charles Court on behalf of the Liberal and National Parties at meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention. The Whitlam solution is simply, without more, to remove from section 53 of the Constitution any power of the Senate to reject or 'in any other manner block' money Bills. The Court solution, on the other hand, would confirm and institutionalise the Senate's existing stranglehold over the House of Representatives by requiring an automatic double dissolution, without vice-regal intervention, in the event that the Senate failed to pass a Bill ' Appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government' within 30 days.

When these provisions were debated at the Perth Constitutional Convention in July 1978, the Court proposal was adopted following a close division on party lines. Standing Committee D of the Convention subsequently gave the Court proposal detailed drafting consideration, and, with some alteration, it was ' noted and approved' by the Adelaide Convention but, given the record of abject failure of referendum proposals that have failed to secure a significant measure of cross-party support, it remains unlikely that it will ever be put to referendum. Equally it must be acknowledged that the Whitlam proposal, were it to be put to referendum in the reasonably foreseeable future, would probably not have a much greater chance of success.

The fixed term parliaments proposal, in the form in which it has emerged from the Senate, amounts to an indirect solution to the problem-a second best solution, perhaps, for everyone, but one which does not involve for either side a confession of past error or loss of present face, and which as such is more politically realistic than any available alternative. The Senate's Supply- blocking power under section 53 of the Constitution remains unamended by the present Bill, as does the Governor-General's reserve power to dismiss a government. The overwhelming likelihood in practice, however, if the Constitution were amended as proposed, is that the power to block Supply would not be destructively exercised, and that the occasion would not, accordingly, arise for the Governor-General to exercise his own power to dismiss.

The argument, in summary, is that the basic constitutional prohibition of premature elections would make the blocking of Supply in most circumstances pointless and politically counter-productive. To the extent that the basic prohibition could be avoided in a particular case-for example by the existence, at the time of the blocking, of some deadlocked measure, for which the double dissolution 'trigger' was already cocked, as was the case in both 1974 and 1975- then the rule that an incoming government could only serve out the term of its predecessor would operate in nearly every case as an overwhelming practical disincentive to the Senate pursuing the matter.
The Bill
It is appropriate at this point to explain the main elements in the Bill in a little more detail.
BASIC FIXED TERM RULE

New section 28 of the Constitution-clause 6 of the Bill-provides for a three- year term for the House of Representatives, with elections in future being required to be held, subject to two specific exceptions, on the third Saturday in November every third year, following expiry of the Parliament on the last Thursday in October. New section 5-clause 2 of the Bill-provides that the Governor-General has no power, subject again to the two exceptions, to dissolve the Parliament other than at this time. By amendments to sections 7 and 13 of the Constitution-clauses 3 and 5 respectively of the Bill-Senate terms are described as equivalent to two House of Representatives terms, and the conditions are created for Senate elections to be always held at the same time as House of Representatives elections. Further, amendments to sections 12 and 32 of the Constitution-in clauses 5 and 7 of the Bill-ensure that writs for House and Senate elections are issued at the proper time.
FIRST EXCEPTION: NO CONFIDENCE RESOLUTION

New section 5 of the Constitution-clause 2 of the Bill-provides for the House to be dissolved in the event that a formal resolution of no confidence, of which at least 24 hours notice has to be given, is passed against the Government, and that there is no further resolution passed by the House within seven days expressing confidence in an alternative Ministry. The House is expressly required to meet within seven days, if it is not otherwise scheduled to do so, in order that this confidence question can be tested.
SECOND EXCEPTION: SENATE DEADLOCK

The only other circumstance enabling an early election to be called in breach of the basic fixed term rule will be the case of a sustained deadlock-of 90 days or more-between the House of Representatives and the Senate, which the Government in the House of Representatives chooses to break by advising a double dissolution. Under the provisions of existing section 57 of the Constitution which govern double dissolutions, this exception will not apply in the six months before the due election date.
RESTORING THE ELECTION CYCLE AFTER AN EXTRAORDINARY DISSOLUTION

New Section 28 of the Constitution-Clause 6 provides that following extraordinary dissolutions of the Parliament under one or other of the two exceptions, the newly-elected Parliament will only serve out the remainder of the original term, rather than commencing a new three-year cycle-unless the dissolution occurs within three months of the expiry of the House of Representatives, in which case a three-year cycle would commence thereafter. This means that, in the case of a successful no confidence resolution under the first exception, only the House of Representatives would go to the polls, with the next House of Representatives and half-Senate elections occurring at the ordinary scheduled time. In the event of a double dissolution under the second exception, both Houses would go to the polls. The 'short term' senators this elected would be due for re-election at the House of Representatives/half-Senate election at the next ordinary scheduled time.
Section 13 Amendment

At this point it is convenient to explain the one addition of substance to the 1982 Bill-there are other drafting changes-namely, the incorporation into it of the Convention regarding section 13 of the Constitution which was unanimously approved by the Adelaide meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention. After a double dissolution the Senate is required by section 13 to divide its members into 'short term' senators and 'long term' senators so that the cycle of Senate rotation can recommence. The practice of allocating senators to 'short term' and 'long term' lists according to their relative success at the preceding election has invariably been followed and the view has now been unanimously accepted by the Convention that this practice is of such importance that it should be written into the Constitution. The opportunity is now being taken to do just that.
Objections to the Proposal-and Responses

A number of objections to the Bill, and the concepts underlying it, were made in the course of the Senate debate last year, which it is reasonable to anticipate may recur in the course of the present debate. Although these objections were either accommodated by Committee stage amendments, or answered in the second reading reply on 19 August 1982 and in the subsequent Senate Committee debate, it may be helpful to honourable senators to summarise those objections which have been most vigorously pressed, and indicate the way in which they may be answered.

'IMPOSSIBLE TO REMOVE A BAD GOVERNMENT': It is said there must be a provision for an election to be held when a government in the House of Representatives loses its majority and no other government can be formed which has the confidence of the House of Representatives. The answer to that objection is that the fixed term concept must of course be qualified in order to retain a Westminster parliamentary system which accommodates that contingency. The Bill makes express provision for this in the no confidence procedure set out in new section 5, clause 2.

'A NEW GOVERNMENT COULD BE FORMED WITHOUT AN ELECTION': It is said there must be an election whenever a new government is formed, and that the Bill is deficient to the extent that it does not allow for this. The system of responsible government demands, so the argument runs, that there not be new governments formed simply by the ebb and flow of majorities within a chamber but that whenever a government loses the confidence of the chamber for any reason, then without waiting to test whether some other government can be formed with a majority, an election ought to be held. To the extent that the fixed term parliament concept as here proposed would rule that out, it is said to interfere with the principles of responsible government. In answer to that objection, it is acknowledged that the Bill does not provide for any mechanism to deal with that situation. On the contrary, it makes provision for a new government to be formed, after the existing one loses the confidence of the House of Representatives, without an election being held if that new government can win a confidence vote in the House of Representatives. But it amounts to a misunderstanding of the Westminster system of responsible government to demand more than that of this proposal and require that an election be necessary in those circumstances. Precedents for such changes of government, under the existing Constitution, occurred in 1903, 1904 twice, 1905, 1908, 1908, 1909, 1917 and 1941.

'THERE WOULD BE NO OPPORTUNITY FOR A GOVERNMENT TO RENEW ITS MANDATE': This objection is put in two different ways. First it is argued that the government of the day needs to have the opportunity to seek a double dissolution if it is being obstructed in its legislative program by a hostile Senate. In reply, it need only be said that the Bill in its present form accommodates this form of the objection by providing for the retention of the double dissolution provision in its present form. The second version of this objection says that the opportunity is needed for the Government to renew its mandate if it has some controversial measure that it wants community support for, or if it is in a position where it lacks, on most of the measures that it puts up, the support of the House of Representatives but where no-one is prepared to move a no confidence motion in the government. The answer here is that it simply is one of the restrictions which the fixed term parliament concept imposes-in our view clearly outweighed by the advantages which the fixed term confers-that a government is not able to renew its mandate in situations of real or imagined difficulties within the lower House itself. Such situations are relatively unlikely to arise as long as the party system continues to operate in its present fashion, and to the extent that they do arise, we consider that the limitation of the Government's ability to call an early election is amply compensated by the benefits of fixed terms systems, above all in terms of stability and predictability of the electoral cycle.

'THE QUALIFICATIONS MEAN THAT THERE ARE NOT REALLY FIXED TERMS AT ALL': It is said that if there are any qualifications at all to enable an extraordinary election of the House of Representatives or to enable a double dissolution in the circumstances of upper House disruption, this is no longer a fixed term parliament system. It is not really a fixed term system, it is said, as long as the government of the day can manipulate these kinds of exception provisions to its own advantage. One way it could do so, it is suggested, is by passing a no confidence motion in itself in the House of Representatives as a purely formal device to get itself to the polls on an earlier date-as has now happened twice with a similar provision in the West German Constitution. Another possibility, much more likely in practice, is that the double dissolution provisions could be very easily manipulated by a government simply by throwing up to the Senate some manifestly unconscionable proposition and using the Senate's rejection of it as a trigger in the hands of the government, to be used any time it pleases, to obtain a dissolution not just of the House of Representatives at a politically opportune time but of the whole Senate as well.

This objection highlighted a problem in the original version of the Bill but it has largely been countered by an amendment to the Bill introduced during the Senate debate. The Bill now contains a very significant disincentive to the artificial manipulation of the extraordinary election exceptions. The disincentive is that the government which is elected following an early election , held under either of the extraordinary procedures, holds office only for the remainder of the original three-year cycle. Thus if a government has served two years of its term and decides that an immediate election would be preferable to an election in 12 months time, it obtains no advantage from seeking an early election since, if re-elected, it would hold office only for the remainder of the cycle; that is, 12 months, at the end of which time it would again have to face the electorate.

'THE CHANGE WOULD NOT SOLVE THE PROBLEM OF SENATE POWER': It is argued that there is nothing to stop the Senate blocking Supply just because of the fixed term rule being in the Constitution. Either there may be double dissolution Bills already in existence of which the Senate can take advantage at the time it blocks Supply, in exactly the same way as occurred in 1974 and 1975 when there were, fortuitously, double dissolution Bills already in existence; or alternatively, it is said, the Senate could block Supply, and insist that the House of Representatives resolve the impasse thus created, by passing a vote of no confidence in itself.

One possible answer is that these are theoretical options only as far as the Senate is concerned and that the Senate just will not block Supply as a matter of practical political dynamics: If it cannot easily force an election by doing so it will not risk the hostility or political obloquy that would be involved in doing so. Another practical answer is that the House of Representatives will be careful in future to avoid creating double dissolution triggers to avoid just that possibility of the Senate taking advantage of a fortuitous section 57 trigger being in place. But the best answer is an extension of that previously given: The combination of technical obstacles to early dissolution, and the rule that the new government could see out only the remainder of the term of its predecessor, would operate in nearly every case as an overwhelming practical disincentive.

A further argument is put that the Senate might block Supply not with the intention of forcing the government of the day to the polls but rather with the intention of forcing concessions from the government of the day as far as the Budget was concerned, forcing actual changes to the Bill rather in the way that occurs in the United States of America at the moment. The most one can say here is that this option has always been available under the present arrangements, that it has never been exercised, and there is no reason to suppose that the establishment of the fixed term system will make it any more likely in practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—It can make requests.

SPEECH.PARA: 'TO THE EXTENT THAT THE CHANGE WILL LIMIT THE SENATE'S POWER TO BLOCK SUPPLY, IT WILL UNDERMINE ITS STATUS AND CREDIBILITY': It is objected, finally, that to the extent that the fixed term parliament concept will solve the problem of Senate power with respect to money Bills, it is inconsistent with the credibility and status of the Senate as an institution for its powers to be limited in this way or its status to be changed in this way. The answer is simply that there is no necessary connection between the powers of the Senate, formal or practical, with respect to money Bills and its status and authority as a chamber of the Parliament. The two are not inextricably intertwined. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party is of the view that the status of the Senate will be considerably enhanced if its powers over money Bills are removed altogether and its role as a House of review is clearly defined. There is much that this and other upper Houses can do in improving legislation, scrutinising the Executive, monitoring the bureaucracy and initiating and generating ideas. None of those functions will be impinged upon in any way by the implementation of the fixed term system.
Conclusion

Mr Deputy President, as you will appreciate, this Bill is-as was said at the outset-a serious minded and realistic attempt to grapple with questions of fundamental constitutional importance, and of crucial importance to the future practical working of our parliamentary system. It is a genuine attempt to find a possible middle-of-the-road solution to problems which have been-and should be- weighing heavily on those of us on both sides of the chamber who simply want to ensure, in the interests of the Australian people, that the political system can work-not only in times of serenity but also in times of passion and crisis.

The subject matter is such that the temptation to score cheap political points is obvious. But it is a temptation which has been resisted in this speech-as it was in most contributions to last year's Senate debate-and hopefully it will be in subsequent contributions to the debate in this house. The only way constitutional reform on this or any other issue can be achieved is through consensus. The Senate has shown how that consensus might evolve and it is now up to us to put the proposal to referendum. The overwhelming support indicated by a recent public opinion poll for the idea of fixed terms, which was of the order of 70 per cent in every State, is an encouraging sign that the referendum will be carried. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Significance and Purpose

This Bill, which has been developed over a decade, commencing with the Sydney meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1973, is being put before the Parliament with a view to enabling the people of Australia to express their views on a proposal to facilitate flexible interchanges of power between the Commonwealth and the States. The objective which we are trying to accomplish through this proposed constitutional amendment is to establish machinery whereby legislative powers can be vested by the Commonwealth in the States in areas previously outside their jurisdiction and to facilitate also the reference of powers by the States to the Commonwealth.

The Constitution at present makes provision in section 51 (xxxvii) for references of legislative power by the States to the Commonwealth Parliament. This provision has been used relatively little, largely because of the doubts that have been held by the States at to whether a reference one gives could be revoked and whether a reference could be limited in time to a term of years and made subject to conditions. Examples of how the existing reference power has been used are the references by the governments of Queensland and Tasmania which have enabled Trans Australia Airlines to provide air services within those States over the last 30 years.

The constitutional amendment proposal before the Senate contains two principal reforms. First, it corrects the present one-sided situation in which the States may refer powers to the Commonwealth but the Commonwealth is unable to refer any of its exclusive powers to the States. The Bill authorises references, which for technical reasons are described in the Bill as 'designations', of powers by the Commonwealth Parliament to the States. These references may be made only on the basis that they are available to all States and not just to particular States. If this proposal is adopted it will mean that the Commonwealth is in a position where it can confer on the States the power, for example, to impose duties of excise, and to legislate in respect of matters involving Commonwealth places- both heads of power which are at present exclusively in the Commonwealth domain.

Secondly, the Bill will overcome any doubts which the States have held as to the basis on which references may be made by them to the Commonwealth. The Bill makes it clear that a reference given by the States will be revocable, that it may be given subject to conditions, including conditions regulating the type of laws that can be passed under it, and that such references may be made for a limited period. Designations of matters by the Commonwealth Parliament will be subject to the same provisions as those relating to references by the States in relation to revocation, the power to impose conditions and like matters.
History

The history of this proposal is worth recounting briefly. The original interchange of powers proposal arose from formal submissions made to the Sydney meeting of the Convention in 1973 by the then coalition Government of New South Wales and the then Liberal Government of Victoria. The New South Wales submission was in these terms:
At present uncertainties exist as to the manner in which placitum (xxxvii) of s. 51-the 'reference power' -operates.
The limited use made of the power in the past is no doubt attributable in large measure to such uncertainties.

It is considered that, by constitutional amendment, these uncertainties should be removed by providing, for example, that references of legislative power by States to the Commonwealth may be made for limited terms and that repeal of a reference Act has constitutional efficacy, and also that the Commonwealth Parliament might refer to the States any legislative power of the Commonwealth.

The Victorian submission was along similar lines although it focused on removing the uncertainties as to the scope of the reference power in section 51 (xxxvii). At the 1973 Convention the heads of the Commonwealth and all of the State delegations except that of Queensland met and agreed on the principle of references of power either way and the removal of existing doubts about the operations of the reference power of the States under section 51 (xxxvii). The then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, announced to the Convention the intention of the Commonwealth Government that in any interchange of powers, whether from the Commonwealth to the States or vice versa, the same provisions should apply as to duration, revocability and the power to apply terms and conditions. The Prime Minister's announcement was followed by statements from the leaders of all State delegations welcoming the proposal.

The Convention referred the matter to Standing Committee B which endorsed a Bill prepared early in 1974 by the Commonwealth, subject to a reservation that was later met by the Federal Government, by incorporating in the Bill a requirement that a designation by the Commonwealth must be made in favour of all States, as the present Bill does. The 1974 Bill, after passing through the House of Representatives, was deferred by the Senate until after it had been considered by all State governments and the Australian Constitutional Convention . The Bill lapsed before these requirements could be met.
At each of the following four convention meetings held in Melbourne in 1975, Hobart in 1976, Perth in 1976 and late last month in Adelaide the proposal--

TALK.START.PARA: —Perth in 1978.

—Perth in 1978. I am indebted to Senator Rae. I am delighted to see that he is still listening. At each of the following four Convention meetings held in Melbourne in 1975, Hobart in 1976, Perth in 1978 and late last month in Adelaide the proposal, as embodied in a Bill drafted in September 1975, was endorsed either in detail or in principle, on the last two of these occasions unanimously. I hope Senator Rae's interjection indicates that we will get his support when it comes to the referendum on this matter.
—I'll do a deal with you. If you support mine I will support yours.

—Will the honourable senator show me his too? In 1976 the then Premier of Victoria, Mr Hamer, said in relation to the motion before the Convention approving the 1975 Bill that it was the Convention's:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . greatest single chance of achieving a really important change in the Constitution which will at one stroke give it a flexibility and responsiveness it does not yet have, and an ability to deal with situations as they arise, without any of the partners-Federal or State-surrendering any of the powers or discretions they now have.

Since 1978 the proposal has been closely considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, by the committees of Solicitors-General and Parliamentary Counsel prior to its most recent endorsement by the Australian Constitutional Convention meeting in Adelaide. Despite this long history, the people of Australia have not yet had the opportunity of voting on the matter at a referendum. Given the advantages of the proposal, the time and effort that have been expended in refining the original idea and the Adelaide Convention's unanimous endorsement a few weeks ago of a resolution, in terms which are faithfully reflected in this Bill, it is appropriate that the referendum question be now submitted to the electorate. The resolution was as follows:

That this Convention approves a constitutional amendment to enable an interchange of powers between the Commonwealth and the States in the form of the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill 1975, provided that the matters which can be designated under section 108A are confined to:
(A) matters which are already within Commonwealth power; and
(B) the empowering of State Parliaments to vest in Federal courts (other than the High Court) Jurisdiction, both original and appellate, in matters arising under state law.

In all the circumstances I believe it can be said that this is truly a consensus proposal. All of the principles developed over the years in relation to the proposal-principles which have been supported on all sides-are fully implemented in this Bill.
Criticisms of the 1975 Bill

The principal criticism made in respect of the 1975 Bill, which has been reiterated for some years by the former Attorney-General of Western Australia, Mr Medcalf, related to a clause which would have meant that the power of the Commonwealth Parliament to designate a matter was not limited by other provisions of the Constitution such as sections 51 (ii) and 99 which prohibit the Commonwealth from discriminating between States. The Government has been sympathetic to the objection, and at Adelaide supported the amendment to the form of the Bill put forward by an Opposition member of the New South Wales delegation to the Convention, to the effect that subject to one exception the Commonwealth's power to designate matters should be restricted to matters in respect of which it clearly has exclusive power under the Constitution.

The exception is in relation to the power of the Commonwealth to empower State parliaments, should they so wish, to vest some matters of State jurisdiction in Federal courts. As I said at the Adelaide Convention, this notion of an ability in State parliaments to vest matters of State jurisdiction in Federal courts can be one solution to the problem of divided jurisdiction that has been the subject of much discussion recently in the context of the proposed integrated court system.

The only reason for making specific provision for the vesting of State jurisdiction in Federal courts is that there is at present some constitutional uncertainty as to whether the Commonwealth Parliament can empower State parliaments to vest State jurisdiction in Federal courts. To put the matter beyond doubt appropriate language has been used in the Bill to ensure that such a power can be conferred should the States be willing to exercise it in particular cases.
Summing Up

This is a highly constructive measure. It creates a framework which has considerable potential to facilitate greater co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States in the interests of the public. The interchange of powers provided for by the Bill involves voluntary action by the Commonwealth and the States which could assist the States to raise additional revenue and to have firmly based powers in relation to Commonwealth places such as airports and post offices. By clarifying and facilitating references of State legislative powers to the Commonwealth the chances of obtaining uniform defamation laws and comprehensive family law powers at Commonwealth level should be increased.

The reference of a matter by a State to the Commonwealth or vice versa would not, of itself, prevent the parliament which had referred the power from passing legislation concerning that matter. This aspect, together with the power of the referring parliament to impose conditions upon its reference of power and to revoke the power at any time, makes the proposal a very flexible one. This should improve the efficiency of government at both Federal and State levels. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

A proposed constitutional alteration to allow Commonwealth and State governments to obtain advisory opinions from the High Court on certain important questions of constitutional law was recommended by the Judicature Committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1977. At about the same time, and quite independently, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs compiled its report in favour of an advisory jurisdiction for the High Court. When the Constitutional Convention met in Perth in 1978 it endorsed-by 54 votes to 36-the Judicature Committee's recommendations by a substantial majority. The Senate Committee's recommendation, which differed on points of detail, was not put to the vote but was circulated for the information of delegates.

Following the Perth meeting, the Convention's Standing Committee-Standing Committee D-undertook a range of inquiries on matters referred to it by the Perth Convention. At Senator Durack's initiative it reactivated consideration of advisory opinions with a view to synthesizing, if possible, the recommendations of the Judicature Committee and those of the Senate Committee. Discussions took place between representatives of the two committees and agreement was reached on a revised proposal which slightly broadened the jurisdiction. The revised proposal was again considered by the Convention at its recent Adelaide meeting and again was approved by a substantial majority-51 to 35. At both the Perth and the Adelaide conventions the advisory opinions proposal was-I am pleased to report-supported by Federal Liberal and National Party delegates. In moving the endorsement of the revised proposal at Adelaide Senator Tate pointed out that an advisory jurisdiction is perfectly consistent with the exercise of judicial power and the independence of the judiciary. Senator Tate stated:

It needs to be emphasised from the outset that the proposal sought to confer on our highest tribunal a further dimension of judicial power, which it had disabled itself from exercising in 1927. We are not dealing with mere political advice or some adjunct to the Executive of Parliamentary functions, but with questions of law only, and that needs to be emphasised. We are dealing with questions of large and radical moment, undoubtedly, but nevertheless true questions of law, particularly apt to be vested in the ultimate arbiter of constitutional issues. Indeed, the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council has stated that, in relation to a similar Canadian jurisdiction, it is a true exercise of judicial power and, indeed, the court of the Judicial Committee itself exercises such an advisory jurisdiction.
The Arguments

The arguments in favour of and against advisory opinions have now been canvassed in some detail in the reports of the Senate Committee of the Convention's Judicature Committee and of Standing Committee D as well as in the proceedings of the Perth and Adelaide conventions. In broad terms the arguments in favour are: First, advisory opinions would save taxpayers expense and resources by enabling governments to check the constitutional validity of major proposals at an early stage; secondly, by enabling rulings to be obtained at an early stage, they would reduce the tendency for differing perceptions of major constitutional issues to develop into matters of political confrontation; and thirdly, they would assist in the development of a more rational basis for the planning of major constitutional initiatives.

The arguments that have been put against advisory opinions can be broadly categorised as follows: First, the independence of the judiciary-it is said that advisory opinions would make the High Court into an adjunct of government and sap its independence; secondly, the danger of overloading the Court; thirdly, the difficulty of giving an opinion in the absence of a concrete fact situation; fourthly, the uncertain status of advisory opinions; and, fifthly, the availability of alternative means of adjudication such as the declaratory judgment.

In relation to the fears expressed for the Court's independence and work-load the simple fact is that these fears have not been realised in Canada where the Supreme Court has had an advisory jurisdiction for many years. Moreover, the careful limitation on the making of references that is contained in the Bill would, I believe, rule out any abuse of the process. Provision is also made for facts to be specified in some detail for the purpose of a reference and, where necessary, for references to be amended. So far as the status of advisory opinions is concerned, it is clear that governments would observe them as they observe other court rulings. It is true that advisory opinions would be subject to being overruled at a later date but that is also true of any High Court decision.

The last argument is that other means-the declaratory judgment is usually instanced-are available for testing the validity of legislation. While it is true that the increasing readiness of the High Court to hear actions for a declaratory judgment, at the suit of the Commonwealth or a State attorney- general, has assisted good government, there are still occasions where such means are not available or are inappropriate. By way of example of the potential usefulness of an advisory jurisdiction I mention the lengthy time it took for the establishment of an effective Trade Practices Commission and the virtual paralysis for a year of the office of the Commissioner while the first legislation was under challenge. Even where the declaratory judgment procedure is available, there are advantages in being able to obtain a ruling without seeking it in the adversary system.
The Bill

It only remains for me briefly to explain those aspects of the Bill which I have not dealt with in outlining the arguments for and against it. References may be made on the validity of any Act or any Bill which is before the Parliament and on certain questions of great constitutional importance which have arisen or are likely to arise. References on Commonwealth matters are to be sought only by the Commonwealth Government and references on State matters are to be sought only by the State government concerned. Provision is also made for the Northern Territory and any other self-governing territory to avail itself of the procedure in relation to its own legislation and territory constitutional questions.
Conclusion

An advisory jurisdiction will not eliminate the need for judicial review. Nor will it reduce the responsibility of governments to act within the constraints of the Constitution. Used selectively, however, it should be effective in minimising unconstitutional legislation and in facilitating the proper development of major government initiatives. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (REMOVAL OF OUTMODED AND EXPENDED PROVISIONS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Constitution is now 82 years old. One of the tasks it performed in 1901 was to unite six British colonies into a Federal Commonwealth and to lay the basis for full national sovereignty. In so doing it was necessary for it to include a large number of provisions dealing with transitional matters which ceased to have any significance five or ten years after Federation and which should now be removed. It was also necessary for the Constitution to make interim provision for a number of other matters pending the enactment of Federal legislation. Provisions of this kind are scattered throughout the Constitution and can be readily identified by the draftsman's tag 'until the Parliament otherwise provides'. To some extent these provisions are a source of Commonwealth power and care needs to be taken in identifying those provisions which can safely be regarded as 'outmoded' or 'spent'. A third category covers those provisions which, having regard to Australia's status as a fully sovereign nation state, are no longer appropriate since they derive from, and reflect, an earlier colonial way of thinking.

The removal of outmoded provisions of these kinds from our Constitution will amount to a pruning of dead wood so that the document will be uncluttered-or at least less cluttered-by irrelevancies of a bygone era. It will not, however, make any change of substance to the Constitution and is therefore an exercise which can be justified only when other proposals are also to go to referendum. An attempt to identify all the constitutional provisions which could safely be removed so as to modernise the text of the Constitution without making changes of substance was carried out by a bipartisan working party of the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1974 convened by Mr Terry McRae, the present Speaker of the House of Assembly of South Australia and Chairman of the recent Adelaide Convention. Following the completion of that working party's report most of its recommendations were endorsed by the then Standing Committee C of the Convention and that Committee's recommendations were unanimously approved by the Hobart Convention in 1976. There the matter rested until the recent Adelaide Convention unanimously approved a further proposal for the incorporation of particular 'practices' into the Constitution. That resolution also involved the removal of some outmoded provisions.
The Bill

The Bill largely reflects the Hobart resolution of the Convention and incorporates the recommendations made by the Adelaide Convention. Two further matters are included. The first is the removal of the transitional provisions which were inserted in 1977. They related to Senate casual vacancies at the commencement of that constitutional alteration and no longer have any operation. The second is the repeal of section 89, which provided for the distribution of the 'federal surplus' before the uniform tariff was imposed. That provision is clearly of no further relevance and ought to be repealed. It appears to have been inadvertently left out of the Hobart resolution.

Some recommendations contained in the Hobart resolution have not been incorporated in the Bill. In most cases this is for technical reasons. For example, changes to the 'covering clauses' of the Constitution raise a number of esoteric issues and it may be more appropriate to regard the covering clauses- which are not part of the Constitution itself but form the first eight sections of the British Act which contains the Constitution-as simply part of the historical context of the Constitution. Some other recommendations from the Hobart resolution have been omitted because they would themselves involve further complicating the text of the Constitution by writing in lengthy savings clauses. Others are superseded by the fixed term proposal.

Without going into excessive detail of the various changes in the Bill, it may assist the Senate if I briefly indicate the provisions in each category which it is proposed to remove. The transitional provisions are:
The last four paragraphs of section 15 dealing with Senate casual vacancies;
section 26, which deals with representation in the first Parliament;
the second paragraph of section 83 which deals with expenditure in the first month of the life of the Commonwealth;
the last paragraph of section 84 dealing with the rights of State public servants transferred to the Commonwealth at its establishment;

that part of section 85 which provides for the contingency that certain property transferred from the States at Federation may be returned to the States at some stage-among the property transferred at Federation were some post offices and Customs houses; if it were proposed to transfer such property to a State this could be done independently of section 85;
section 86, by virtue of which, the collection and control of duties of Customs and of excise and control of the payment of bounties passed to the Commonwealth;
section 89, which provided for the distribution of surplus revenue to the States until the imposition of the uniform tariff;
the savings provision in section 90 concerning grants or agreements for bounties made before 30 June 1898;
the second paragraph of section 92, which provided for duties to be imposed on the interstate movement of goods which had been imported into a State before the imposition of the uniform tariff;

section 95, which made special provision for Western Australia during the first five years after Federation by enabling that State to impose Customs duties during that period which were to be collected by the Commonwealth; and
the last paragraph of section 125, which provides that the Parliament shall sit at Melbourne until it meets at the seat of government.
In the second category of interim provisions employing the formula 'until the Parliament otherwise provides' are:

Section 87, which provides for the distribution of three quarters of the Commonwealth revenue from customs and excise to the States for the first 10 years after Federation and thereafter 'until the Parliament otherwise provides'. I interpolate that this became known as the 'Braddon clause' or the 'Braddon blot' and was a compromise typical in the nineteenth century concern with the allocation of Federal revenue. It no longer has any practical application. The Commonwealth abandoned the formula in 1910 and instituted a States grants scheme in its place.

Section 93, which provided for the payment to the States of surplus revenue during the first five years after the imposition of the uniform tariff 'and thereafter until the Parliament otherwise provides' on a similar basis to that provided for in Section 89. This provision ceased to have any practical effect in 1907.

The final category of provisions-those which have been unanimously accepted by the Convention as no longer appropriate to Australia's status as a sovereign nation-are: The reference in Section 58 to the Governor-General's power to reserve Bills for the Queen's assent; Section 59 which empowers the Queen to disallow any Commonwealth law within one year of the Governor-General's assent; Section 60 which concerns signification of the Queen's assent to reserved Bills; and the reference in Section 74 to the reservation of Bills limiting appeals to the Privy Council. The alterations of Sections 58 and 74 and the repeal of Section 59 were included in the Adelaide resolution. The repeal of Section 59 was also included in the Hobart resolution. The unanimous endorsement of these resolutions provides ground for hope that the removal of all the outmoded provisions dealt with in the Bill will represent a start on the task of modernising our Constitution in a systematic way. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has taken the time of the Senate for a number of months. In fact we are now in our fiftieth hour of debate on a topic which in many ways could have been dispensed with in a much shorter period. This morning's news reports led with headlines to the effect that the same tired old arguments had been brought up in the Senate as a consequence of the introduction of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. In fact, in the last two days we have had another stanza of the long, tired and drawn-out debate. Nothing new of substance has been raised by those uncontrollable back benchers on the other side. All we have had is a continuation of the frustration of the orderly workings of this place. We could analyse the performance of the Opposition back bench as parliamentary guerrilla tactics at their worst-45 to 50 hours of tiresome debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The people who are losing because of this performance are the Tasmanian people. Because of the low-level, fear politics which have been exercised both in this chamber and in the other place, because of the obsession with tags such as 'spy flights' and because of the obsession with some antiquated concept of what are now paraded as States' rights the Tasmanian people and their interests have been forgotten altogether. It is no wonder that people in the rest of Australia are starting to tire of the performance of the Liberal Party Opposition. It is no wonder that we have reached the stage at which people in many places, including South Australia, are referring to the incident of the F111 flights-to use a film title-as One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, Part 2. It is no wonder that not only the rest of the Australian people but also the Tasmanian people are concerned about what is happening in this place.

We as a government are concerned about the protection of our natural and cultural heritage. We maintain that we have a moral and a legal obligation to do that. In this instance the heritage we are concerned about is the wilderness section of South West Tasmania. Wilderness has been defined many times and I need not go into a lengthy definition of it. Wilderness, for the purpose of this debate, is an area where the earth and its community of life are untrammelled by man. I submit that there is no real contest in respect to this point. I recollect towards the end of last year talking to Senator Walters, who asked me what I would be doing over the Christmas break. I suggested I might go to Tasmania. She said that in doing so I should make a point of seeing the South West because it is a most beautiful part of the world. Even Senator Walters accepted quite grudgingly that that area has some extreme value. Without going to the extent of recognising that it should be preserved, she accepted that it had some value which made it important for me to see.

What is in question in this debate is the survival of a uniquely beautiful area of both cultural and environmental significance world wide. This is what we are concerned about. I need not say any more but quote the Tasmanian Director of Tourism, Mr J. B. Holten, who in 1979 said:
Within the bounds of flexible planning, including reasonable access and strict management, the South West could become one of the great visitor destinations in the world.

That presents the side of the economic argument to which the Opposition is not prepared to address itself: As a tourist attraction that untrammelled part of the world, with planning and management, could provide industry and jobs for Tasmania. We are, and we have been this morning, continually confronted with the argument of States' rights but one thing that should be mentioned again and again in response to the speeches of people such as Senator Crichton-Browne, who made a point this morning about the mad grab for power by Federal Labor governments, is that it was a Federal Liberal Government which pursued the Koowarta case to the High Court. It was a Federal Liberal Government which sought the power that the High Court then gave it and it was a Federal Liberal Government which, in fact, wanted to exercise that power. That grab for power, as it has been called, is not something that this Labor Government initiated. We do not classify it as a grab for power. The point has to be made that at the moment we are witnessing from the Opposition a selective application of not only principles but also the Constitution. It is something that, despite 50 hours of debate, the Opposition in this place has not been able to understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that is what the corporations power intended?

—The corporations power, as were many other powers in the Constitution, was introduced and put into the Constitution about 80 years ago. I am sure that even Senator Crichton-Browne can understand that in the last 80 years there have been developments not only in South Australia but also in Western Australia and the rest of the world which demanded a flexible and changing constitution, a constitution that can meet the problems that have arisen over the last 80 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the reply which he gave to Senator MacGibbon in the Senate yesterday about the possibility of a judicial inquiry to enable Mr Combe to clear his name. Senator Button indicated in reply that he would convey to the Prime Minister what he described as Senator MacGibbon's 'bizarre suggestion' and that he was sure that the Prime Minister would look at it. In view of the serious questions left unanswered by Mr Hawke's statement and the devastating effect it has had on Mr Combe, will the Government establish a judicial inquiry in regard to the whole affair and the manner in which the Prime Minister has handled it?

—The answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is yes. The Prime Minister set in train over a week ago the mechanisms for establishing a judicial inquiry into this matter. The name of the presiding judge and the terms of reference will be announced next week.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer . Has the Australian Government approved a proposal by two Korean companies, Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation Ltd and Ssangyong Corporation, to each acquire a 20 per cent interest in the Cook colliery in central Queensland? Will the acquisition enable the mine, which was destined for closure, to remain open? Does this approval put paid to criticisms by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, of the Australian Government's foreign investment policy?

—I understand that the situation is as suggested in Senator Colston 's question-that the Cook colliery, which previously had been destined to close, has been kept alive because of the equity partnership of, I think, 40 per cent from the two Korean firms Senator Colston mentioned. The second part of his question is also correct; the Australian Labor Party is not hostile to foreign capital provided the entry of foreign capital is in the national interest. This of course is a clear case where the involvement of a foreign equity partner is in the interest of the people directly employed at the mine, of the region of Queensland and of the nation as a whole. The application of the Government's policy in that correct way contrasts sharply with the attitude towards foreign investment displayed by the Queensland Government a few months ago. The Australian equity partners in the Jackson pipeline, who had already arranged finance for the project and who already had it fully designed and, indeed, under construction, were stood over by the Premier of Queensland and forced to take a foreign equity partner which they neither needed nor wanted. Confronted with that clear case of foreign equity, which was not needed and was probably not in the national interest, the Treasurer last week made the correct decision in endorsing the Foreign Investment Review Board recommendation that the Jackson pipeline equity-foreign equity unnecessarily enforced on the Australian partners by the Queensland Government-not proceed. In the case of the Cook colliery the circumstances are quite different. This Government applies the foreign investment rules in the national interest. The Queensland Government applies them apparently for capricious reasons or whatever other reasons it may have.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the question I asked a few moments ago. The Leader of the Government in the Senate has just told the Senate that a judicial inquiry is to be held and that arrangements have been in hand for about a week. If that is the case, why did he describe the suggestion for a judicial inquiry made by Senator MacGibbon yesterday as bizarre? Why was that very important information withheld by the Prime Minister when he made to the House of Representatives the statement which was later repeated in the Senate?
—I suppose that I answered the question yesterday in the context of regarding most suggestions which come from Senator MacGibbon as bizarre. I do not wish to make light of it in that--

—In any event the important part of the question was why the Prime Minister did not disclose this matter yesterday. I am not in a position to answer that. I take it the reason was that arrangements had to be made for the establishment of a royal commission. It is a matter which will be discussed again on Monday by the Cabinet, but that is the Government's intention. I cannot take that matter any further at this stage.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, refers to newspaper reports of the possibility of a new Syrian- Israeli war and that this war could commence in Lebanon. As the situation is causing deep concern to the Lebanese community in Australia, can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's view of the latest developments in Lebanon ?

—The Government welcomes the agreement which was reached in principle last week between Israel and Lebanon on the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. This has at long last been secured with the assistance of the United States of America Secretary of State, Mr Shultz. The rejection by the Syrian Government of the draft agreement is a matter of concern to the Government. It is hoped that negotiations between Lebanon and Syria will produce agreement that Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organisation forces should also withdraw from Lebanon. The Government has been concerned for a long time by the continuing division of Lebanon by foreign occupying forces. That is a most unsatisfactory situation. It has been the view of the Government that all foreign forces should be withdrawn from Lebanon. We believe that the step which was taken last weekend is a step towards the finality of that process of negotiation and discussion which has gone on for a long time. Australia fully supports the independence and integrity of Lebanon and the restoration of the sovereignty of the Lebanese Government throughout the whole of this territory. We are very anxious that any influence this Government can exert will assist that process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to part of an answer he gave to a question asked by Senator Mason in the Senate on Tuesday, 10 May. I will just quote the relevant part. When he was being questioned about the authenticity of articles in the National Times he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The authenticity of the articles as a whole,or of any particular part of them, is not a matter about which I believe it is proper to comment, certainly at this stage, for reasons that are quite familiar in dealing with security matters of this kind. In a sense an endless succession of questions as to the authenticity of each part of the document-while it may be doing no damage in one particular case-can result in the authenticity, by a process of elimination, of some remaining part being thus established.

I might add that I entirely agree with that totally correct statement of the Attorney-General. I ask: Did the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister agree on the principle of not publicly canvassing issues in which matters of national security are involved at any time prior to the Prime Minister's statement to Caucus on Tuesday? Does the Attorney-General agree that the Prime Minister, by excluding a certain group of people from allegations involving security matters about which questions were being asked-I am not suggesting for one minute that the Prime Minister mentioned Mr Combe's name; he has made that quite clear and I accept that-but--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested by some of your colleagues.

—Not at that stage. Does the Attorney-General agree that, by excluding a certain group of people in the same way as he was being pressed to do by Senator Mason's question, the Prime Minister breached that principle and opened up the whole question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not concede anything of the kind. Of course it is the case that as a matter of general principle and as a general rule the strictures which I advanced in answer to Senator Mason are those which should apply. There are of course, as has always been acknowledged, however, exceptional circumstances that can arise. The honourable senator, indeed even in his question, quoted the phrase I used, which was that 'at this stage' it would be improper for me to canvass any questions of authenticity. That was because no situation of acute need had arisen such as would justify any such answer being given at that stage. Questions of acute need can arise and it may be as important to protect the reputation, credibility and effectiveness of a security organisation on occasion to release some information as to deny the possibility of information ever being given. It is a matter for judgment in all the circumstances of each particular case.
