It does not sit well in the mouth of anyone in the Opposition to chastise the Government for giving a degree of information about a matter when that information has been actively sought by the very people who are now doing the chastising.
—By then it was public knowledge.

—The crucial reason it became public knowledge was of course the activities of the now Opposition parties-in particular Mr Sinclair-in designating Mr Combe openly in Parliament in circumstances in which the scuttlebutt of this Parliament and this capital and indeed most of the informed sources around this nation were identifying the name in question.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the circumstances of the Caucus meeting, I do not propose to give Senator Durack or anyone else a blow by blow description or a sally by sally description of anything that happens in Caucus except to say that one knows perfectly well what contribution would have been made to reasoned debate on this issue by the Opposition had Mr Hawke on that occasion not explicitly denied that any member of the Government or Caucus was the person involved. Had Senator Durack been willing, or if he were willing now, to give an undertaking, as Mr Peacock gave an undertaking privately to Mr Hawke, that no political abuse would be made of information conveyed in private, it would not be necessary for these particular courses of action to be taken by the Prime Minister to set at rest the very hares that the honourable senator has set running.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the tirade we have just had from the Attorney-General-we have become used to them-I ask: Is it not a fact that the question of the association between Mr Ivanov and a leading figure in the Australian Labor Party had become a subject of Press reporting on the Sunday and Monday, long before any such questions were asked by the Opposition? Is it not a fact that there was an Australian Associated Press report of what the Prime Minister said to Caucus before the questions were asked ?
—I have nothing further to add to my previous answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LAND AT WALLGROVE, NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Commonwealth prepared to make available to the State of New South Wales Commonwealth land at Wallgrove in New South Wales for the development of a major recreational park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been protracted negotiations over the years between the Commonwealth and New South Wales-I presume there were similar negotiations with other States-about the release of Crown land or Commonwealth properties for use as recreational areas. This has been the subject of many questions in the Senate. Those negotiations have been protracted. There has been much criticism about the fact that much of the land that is required for recreational purposes in New South Wales has not been readily available. However, I am advised by my colleague Mr John Brown, whom I represent in this place, that he personally favours the proposal that land at Wallgrove should be made available to New South Wales for recreational purposes. However, as so often happens in public administration, the Department of Defence has opposed such a proposal because it believes that the land is suitable for the purpose of a communication facility in the region.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I am advised that it is the view of the Government that the recreational needs of the people who now live in such numbers in the western part of Sydney are important. I remind the Senate that more people now live west of Parramatta than east of it, so that Parramatta in fact now is the centre of the city proper in terms of population. The State Government is very much concerned about the provision of adequate recreational facilities in the developing parts of Sydney. The Government has agreed to discuss with the Royal Australian Air Force section of the Department of Defence the proposal that it should be provided with a site, but not necessarily in the Wallgrove area. The answer to the honourable senator's question is that the Commonwealth is agreeable to meeting the needs of the New South Wales Government and steps are being taken to expedite the discussions with a view to meeting the wishes of the State Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, is based on the proposition that the Government has, wittingly or unwittingly, jeopardised the career of an Australian whose only apparent crime was to earn a living partly from work concerning the Soviet Union. The question is in six parts. Can the Attorney-General state categorically that Mr David Combe at no time--
—Put it on notice.
—I am sorry, I did not hear what was said. Is it not the wish to have this man's name aired and cleared in this place?
—Order! Senator Chipp,will you ask your question, please?
—Mr President, I earn your protection from interjections. If I do not get that I am entitled to answer those interjections.
—I am seeking your co-operation in ignoring the interjection and asking the question. Other honourable senators want to ask questions too.

—I want to ask a question in peace, Mr President. Can the Attorney -General state categorically that Mr David Combe at no time has committed any offence against the Commonwealth? Can the Attorney further state that there is no evidence that Mr Combe gave or was contemplating giving information to Mr Ivanov which could have endangered Australia's security? Does the word used by the Prime Minister that Mr David Combe had been 'compromised' by Mr Ivanov, refer only to a proposed business deal whereby the Soviets were interested in obtaining Mr Combe's services to assist them in buying wheat from Australia and to promote increased trade?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that Mr Combe's legitimate journey to Russia, at its Government's expense, to discuss future business arrangements was the main reason for the Government deciding to act as it did? Does not this Government encourage trade with the Soviet Union, as did its predecessors? Does not the Government maintain a diplomatic mission in the Soviet Union whose members have and must have contact with Soviet officials with the aim of increasing trade with the Soviet Union-which we are led to believe was Mr Combe's role, albeit in a private capacity? Finally, why was Mr Combe not given the right of appeal against and rebuttal of confidential Australian Security Intelligence Organisation recommendations concerning his career beyond the closed meeting with the Attorney-General and the head of ASIO yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question, of which he did have the courtesy to give me two minutes notice. I do not accept the premise on which it is based, namely, that the actions of the Government jeopardised the career of a person in the circumstances he described. I believe that throughout this matter the Government has acted with honour and rigour and with a very real concern for the protection of the rights of the individual concerned. It is only a pity that others have not been so motivated and have not so acted. As to the first question, I state categorically that at no time has Mr Combe committed any offences against the Commonwealth-I take it that Senator Chipp means in the context of this affair. Yes, I am able to say that on all the information available to the Government, both at the time it made its relevant decisions and subsequently, it is my opinion and belief and that of my Department that no offence has been committed. As to questions two, three, four and five which seek the detail, as it were, on which our judgments have been premised and based, I am afraid that I must say to Senator Chipp at this stage that questions of detail of this kind are simply not appropriate to put on the public record except in the most really exceptional circumstances. We have gone some of the distance down the track in order to endeavour to clear the air. But certainly we do not propose, unless some extraordinary situation should arise, to answer specifically-for familiar security reasons-the questions which he has put to me.

ANSWER.PARA: The final question asked why Mr Combe was not given a right of appeal and rebuttal against confidential ASIO recommendations concerning his career beyond the closed meeting with the Attorney-General and the head of ASIO yesterday. I simply say that first of all no such right of appeal is available under existing law for an aggrieved individual. I regard that as a regrettable state of affairs . As I have foreshadowed on many occasions previously, and recently in the context of this affair, this will be one of the matters which will be very much- -

TALK.START.PARA: —But you could have given it to him.
—Oh, shut up! This will be very much one--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Of course all interjections are disorderly but there are interjections in this place which are part of the normal debate. To tell honourable senators to shut up is, in my view , not part of the dignity of this place. I believe the Attorney-General should apologise for that comment and withdraw it.
—If the Attorney-General used the expression about which the Leader of the Opposition complains-I did not pick it up-I ask him to withdraw it .

—Of course I withdraw but I state for the record that it was simply a sotto voce ejaculation of exasperation and not something that was intended to be heard. I will continue where I left off. There is no right of appeal for an aggrieved individual under the existing law. It is proposed that the establishment of such a right of appeal, the arguments for and against it and the way in which it might be accomplished, be one of the terms of reference of the judge whom it is proposed to appoint, as Senator Button said, to a royal commission of inquiry into the operation of security agencies or, at least, ASIO . The terms of reference have not yet been settled. One of the terms of reference will be the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov. It is proposed that for the future machinery will be established and that we will have a basis on which that can occur. As to the circumstances in which Mr Combe' s position was heard and responded to yesterday by the Government, every facility was made available to Mr Combe to present fully, in both documentary form and orally, his view of events. I say further, because it was not perhaps made clear enough yesterday in the Parliament, that the particular statement that was put down yesterday by the Prime Minister was seen and agreed to by Mr Combe as an appropriate statement in all the circumstances of the event.
—The whole statement?

—The whole statement. I spent most of yesterday, with the exception of one hour at Question Time, negotiating with Mr Combe the text of that statement. It was, in that sense, an agreed statement which accurately reflects Mr Combe's assessment of the situation and the propriety of the Government in responding to the situation as it did. The text of the statement makes that clear to the extent that it quotes Mr Combe as saying that he understands and accepts the reasons for the Government's decision being made at the time that it was made.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that that puts at rest to at least some extent-although of course I can understand the sense of indignation and concern that many people feel about the course of events-the circumstances of this case to the extent that they can be put into the public domain and that it will be appreciated that every attempt was made to accommodate Mr Combe's position and to articulate the very real sympathy that the Government felt for him and his position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I sincerely thank the Attorney- General for his very frank answers to questions one and two. At least that goes some way down the track of establishing Mr Combe's position. The supplementary question I intended to ask concerned the Attorney-General's failure to answer my question about the word 'compromised' used by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: The view of the National and International Security Sub-committee was that, as events had developed, Mr Combe either had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him.

In the event that the Attorney-General will give me an undertaking that every word of this statement was agreed to by Mr Combe I will withdraw that question because obviously it would embarrass the Government for security reasons. It is not my wish to do that. May I have an assurance that every word of the Prime Minister's statement was agreed to by Mr Combe?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has that assurance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIA: REPORT ON INDUSTRY AND EMPLOYMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I understand that a second report on Tasmania by Sir Bede Callaghan has been completed but has not been released. Can the Minister give me the reasons for this long delay of almost six years? When will this report be released?

—I do not think it is technically correct to say that there was a second report by Sir Bede Callaghan. In June 1977 he reported on the structure of industry and the employment situation in Tasmania. The report was then published and a Commonwealth-State officials committee was established to consider proposals submitted by Tasmania following the publication of the report . A number of projects were subsequently supported by the Commonwealth Government, such as the Port Arthur development, the native forestry development , the Legana industrial estate and matters such as that which arose from the report. During the four years between June 1977 and August 1981 discussions took place in relation to those matters. In August 1981 the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the Premier of Tasmania agreed on a review of special assistance under the Callaghan proposals for Tasmania, but there was no second Callaghan report. The review, which started in August 1981, is now, I believe, substantially completed and it addresses some of Tasmania's economic problems, but it cannot be finalised until the comments of the Tasmanian Government are received. We hope to receive them in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I address my question to the Attorney-General. It covers some of the ground already traversed by Senator Chipp and the Attorney -General's response to him. I also refer to the statement made yesterday by the Prime Minister that Mr Combe ' ''understands and accepts'' the Government's decision that Ministers not deal with him in his capacity as a consultant lobbyist'. I seek a clear interpretation of the comments in the Prime Minister's statement as to whether Mr Combe accepts both the Government's decision of 2 May and the reasons given to Cabinet for it as well as the view of the National and International Security Sub-committee that he had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Ministers to deal with him. I accept that the Minister has said that Mr Combe agreed with the wording of the statement yesterday, but to me the wording of the statement is not clear enough to extract the information as to whether Mr Combe accepted that he had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Ministers to deal with him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two bases on which the Government decided to sever dealings at a ministerial level and a senior ministerial staff level with Mr Combe, although not in such a way as to destroy his livelihood completely. There is certainly no desire to deny him access to the Public Service or to Ministers' staff or Ministers' offices in order to arrange appointments and so on. I make that point clear for the record because I think there has been some misunderstanding of it. There were two bases on which the Government so acted. The first basis was that which was put to the Cabinet and the Ministry on the dates mentioned in the statement, which was fully debated by the Cabinet and Ministry on the dates mentioned and which was in itself a sufficient reason for the Government to act as it did. That is, as the statement says, the Government' s acceptance of the principle that Mr Combe was in something of a special position by virtue of his very senior position with the party. The Government took the following view:

ANSWER.PARA: Ministers' doors should be, and be seen to be, open without the need for leverage by a party insider; and it was not appropriate that a former party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to government denied to others.

I note that that rationale for the decision made with respect to Mr Combe is not a view of the world that was accepted by our predecessor in office-more is the pity-in relation to some of its previous senior staffers. In relation to that view of the world, and the principle lying behind it, I can say that Mr Combe understands and accepts that that position, viewed entirely in isolation and distinct from the security issue, was a legitimate position for a government to adopt. I cannot pretend that he is happy about it, obviously, because differential access to government is what he was selling, but he does understand and accept that fact. The statement says that and is meant to encompass that.

The second basis for the decision in relation to Mr Combe was, of course, as the Prime Minister has now made abundantly clear, the concern that was felt-not by the whole Government, because the whole Government did not know about it, but by the National and International Security Sub-committee of Cabinet-as the statement said, that Mr Combe's relations with Mr Ivanov, whether wittingly or unwittingly, had got to the point where it was believed that no government could continue to allow that level of direct access. Again as to that, the statement says and is intended to state clearly-I hope there is no ambiguity about it-that Mr Combe does understand and accept that as a basis for the Government's decision. Again, I do not pretend that Mr Combe is other than wounded and distressed by the course of events in which he has found himself caught up. Again I repeat my personal reaction to that wounded feeling and that distress. It has been a difficult period for all of us. But Mr Combe does understand and accept that the Government, on all the information available to it-which was for the most part made available to him yesterday-had effectively no practical alternative to making the decision that it did, on security grounds, quite apart from the other independent ground in relation to dealing with a former party official as a lobbyist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Special Minister of State aware of comments made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and by the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Doug Anthony, labelling the public funding of elections as corrupt? Given that the New South Wales branch of the National Party is now registered for public funding in New South Wales and its leader, Mr Leon Punch, has stated that the National Party will now accept public funds for election purposes, and given that the Liberal Party in New South Wales is now participating in a desperate and hypocritical grab for public funding after campaigning against it in the last State election, is the Minister aware of any moves by the national bodies of the Liberal and National parties to dissociate themselves from or proscribe their New South Wales branches for daring to accept public funds?

—I am not aware of any such dissociation moves. I simply make the point that the absence of such moves would appear to amount to yet another ample demonstration of that unfortunate disposition toward hypocrisy which afflicts our political opponents in most matters, political and financial.

—I direct a question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the fact that Mr Combe's association with Ivanov and the Government's decision on the matter was the subject of several hours of discussion yesterday between Mr Combe and the Attorney-General, part of the discussion being held in the presence of the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, as a result of which Mr Combe allegedly fully understands and accepts the Government' s decision. Does the Attorney-General believe that his role as investigator, prosecutor, judge and executioner is consistent with the basic principles of human rights and civil liberties of which he is such an ardent exponent? Does he also believe that the procedure adopted is consistent with the now announced intention to hold a royal commission?

—I do not accept the premises on which the question is based . I simply make the point that also present at those discussions yesterday for most of the period was Mr Combe's solicitor. If I had endeavoured to act as either judge or executioner, or in any of the other sordid legal ways that Senator Jessop suggested, I think there would be no difficulty about the appropriate legal action being taken. I do not think I have anything to add to my previous answers.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of serious delays occurring in programming Family Court hearings in provincial areas? Can the Attorney-General outline his Department's policy in regard to the appointment of Family Court judges in major regional centres? Can he comment on the urgent need for the appointment of a Family Court judge to be based permanently in Townsville?

—The three largest regional registries of the Family Court are Parramatta, Newcastle and Townsville. I understand that delays in dealing with a defended matter, from the time the matter is ready for hearing to its being heard, are as follows: Parramatta, six months; Newcastle, three months or less; Townsville, approaching 12 months. So there is undoubtedly some foundation for what Senator Reynolds put to me. The placement of judges at particular registries of the Family Court, as opposed to the appointment of new judges to that Court, is a matter for the Chief Judge of the Family Court, who is primarily responsible, of course, for its proper administration. I am in the course of reviewing the judicial requirements of the Court overall and in terms of the possible need for further placements of this kind. My understanding is that until recently, at least, an urgent need for the placement of a Family Court judge in Townsville has not been perceived. But, in the light of the honourable senator's question and the statistics just made available to me, I will certainly examine the reasons for those delays and discuss the matter with the Chief Judge. Might I say further that by virtue of the recent appointment of a further Family Court judge in Brisbane I anticipate that delays in Townsville will very soon be reduced.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and follows the answer which he gave to the last question from the Opposition. I ask: Was Mr Combe made aware, at the time of the interview yesterday and at the time when Mr Combe apparently agreed to the statement that was to be made by the Prime Minister, that a judicial inquiry was to be held?

—I foreshadowed at one point of the discussions with Mr Combe that a royal commission or a similar judicial investigation into the operations of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was likely to be the subject of imminent announcement, as had been foreshadowed by Mr Hawke earlier in the week and by me in more general terms elsewhere. The question of a specific judicial inquiry into the circumstances either of the Ivanov affair or of any particular event associated with that was not raised by me with Mr Combe- on my part simply because the matter had not been the subject of any discussion at a ministerial level. I make it clear that there was certainly no such request from Mr Combe to me for any such--
—I thought you believed in new rules of criminal investigation.

—I will be forced to another sotto voce ejaculation and be less polite. I think I have probably answered the question. I have lost track of my sentence. No doubt the honourable senator will pick it up in a supplementary question if he feels I can further assist him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The other place has been told by the Prime Minister this morning that there will be a full judicial inquiry into three matters, including the involvement of Mr Combe. Was the fact that there would be a judicial inquiry into the involvement of Mr Combe known to Mr Combe yesterday when he agreed to that statement?
—No, because no decision had been made to that effect at that time.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is it a fact that there have been sharp falls in interest rates this week, including a declining yield on 26-week treasury notes from 11.28 per cent last week to 9.86 per cent yesterday, a reduction in the Commonwealth Trading Bank's investment deposit rate by 1.5 percentage points on Tuesday, and a 0.5 per cent reduction in prime overdraft rates by the Australia and New Zealand Bank and the National Australia Bank this week? If so, do money market trends encourage the view that the previous upward spiral in interest rates may at last have been halted? Will the Government closely monitor rates charged by the banks on home mortgages to ensure that interest rate reductions flow on to home buyers at the earliest opportunity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the last part of the question first. Yes, the Government will monitor the movement in interest rates in the way that Senator Maguire suggested. On the first part of the question, from memory very substantial interest rate reductions of the order that the honourable senator indicated have taken place. Indeed, the interest rate on treasury notes-I think it might be the 13-week notes-has fallen by almost 2 per cent to the lowest level in three years. As to what that indicates for the future, experience suggests that people ought to be a little cautious when making predictions. There is no better demonstration of that, I suppose, than the previous Prime Minister's rash assertion in December 1977 that a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates in the next 12 months was a target that could and would be achieved. The Deputy Prime Minister at the time, Mr Anthony, said that if interest rates did not fall by 2 per cent he would eat his hat. Interest rates in the next 12 months in fact went up by 2 or 3 per cent and kept going up for virtually the rest of the life of the thoroughly discredited former Government. They hit record levels-up to 16 per cent on housing borrowings from building societies and just below that on housing borrowings from banks. They were interest rate levels which had never been thought possible at any time in Australia's history.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that interest rates are on a clear and, at this stage, quite rapid downward trend is, of course, a clear vote of confidence by the financial market that this Government is fiscally responsible, unlike the previous Government, and that inflation will be coming down.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it say about the money supply?

—Senator Chaney says: 'What about the money supply?' That gives us some indication of the simplistic views which apparently are still dogma on that side of the chamber. That is one of the reasons why honourable senators opposite are on that side of the chamber. They have all these nostrums based on the belief that there is a simple one-to-one cause and effect-one-shot causes and one-shot solutions, always in a one-to-one ratio. One manifestation of that dogma is that interest rates must increase if the deficit increases. At the very time that the previous Government was pushing interest rates up to all-time record levels the deficit was in fact falling. Interest rates are now declining, in spite of the enormous $10 billion impending deficit which this Government has inherited from its fiscally irresponsible predecessors. If honourable senators opposite cannot think through the theory, one would have thought it would have penetrated even their consciousness that the empirical evidence is in conflict with their dogma.

ANSWER.PARA: In closing I should make one observation about why the previous Government was so insensitive to the enormous interest rates which have done so much damage to so many Australian families and to the Australian building industry. Some members of the previous Government were insensitive to them because they were quarantined from their effects. For example, Mr Anthony had a 45-year loan at 4. 75 per cent for his second house in Canberra. That remained fixed. While everyone else was paying 14 per cent, 15 per cent or 16 per cent, Mr Anthony was paying 4.75 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the house the CIA bloke rented?
—That is right.
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh not to debate the answer and to be precise and brief. He has had about five minutes.

—I was making the point that leading members of the previous Government were certainly insensitive to the interest rates that ordinary people have to pay. Mr Anthony was paying 4.75 per cent interest on a loan for a house that he had lived in for 20 years.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. You intervened at the point when I was rising on a point of order. I draw attention again to Standing Order 100 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . a Senator shall not debate the matter.
There has already been an extensive debate in this answer which is not relevant to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already drawn the Minister's attention to the appropriate Standing Order. I asked him to be brief in the rest of his answer.

—I shall be very brief. I only had about another six words to say. Mr Anthony was insensitive because he had a loan at 4.75 per cent for a house that he had lived in for 20 years, except for the brief period when it was let to the Central Intelligence Agency agent, Mr Stallings.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the desire of quite a large number of persons who served during World War II and who are now over 65 years of age to be transferred from the age pension to the service pension, these service people being those who did not qualify for the service pension? Why cannot their legitimate desire be fulfilled and why can they not now be transferred from the age pension to the service pension in view of the fact that it would cost the Commonwealth little or nothing at all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine asks a very obvious question that has been widely canvassed in ex-service organisations for a number of years. It is a matter that my Department will be discussing in connection with the forthcoming Budget. There is certainly a recognition by the Government that a considerable proportion of World War II veterans are now approaching the age of 60 and therefore qualifying for the service pension. However, it is a matter that involves some degree of extra funding.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has a great deal of sympathy for the matter that has been raised by Senator Harradine but I cannot give any assurances, having regard to the very difficult economic climate the Government has inherited from the conservative regime over the last seven years. Our difficulties are compounded by the size of the deficit and the commitments that the Government has made in the social welfare area. However, I assure both the Senate and the honourable senator concerned that I have a compassionate attitude in respect of this matter and I will do my level best to accommodate the request.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I apologise for asking a supplementary question , but my question related to people who are 65 years of age and over and who are currently receiving the age pension, and asked for a simple transfer of at least those people, in the interim, to the service pension. Will the Minister give that request consideration in the interim, before proceeding to transfer those who are 60 years of age?
—That would require legislative changes. These are matters which, as I have indicated, will be considered in the Budget context.

—Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate provide the Senate with statistics on how many questions the Opposition has asked in this place in the eight Question Times so far this session on the issues of unemployment, interest rates, economic growth, inflation and government deficits ?

—I am totally surprised by the question and do not have the statistics available. I will hazard a guess and say that there have been two such questions since the former Government was defeated in the 5 March election. But I will get the information and make it available to the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General and ask him not to hazard a guess at the answer. I refer to an answer given by Senator Button to the effect that the Prime Minister had set in train over a week ago the mechanisms for establishing a judicial inquiry and his more recent answers with respect to decisions made concerning the judicial inquiry and its relationship to the talk with Mr Combe. When was the decision made to hold a judicial inquiry ? If that decision was taken in stages, what were those stages and when were the various decisions made with respect to the inquiry? By whom were the decisions made? Were they made by the Ministry, by the Cabinet or by a small group of Ministers?

—Maybe I will strike a deal with the honourable senator. If he on behalf of his party adopts an attitude to freedom of information legislation that would accommodate answers to questions of that type being given , I would be happy to answer them now.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to the importance of having adequate career advisers and counsellors, particularly in the Commonwealth Employment Service. In view of both the sharpening increases in unemployment and the depressed job market that the Labor Government has just inherited, can the Minister advise whether greater resources will be made available to streamline and promote these services so that there is effective co -ordination of manpower planning and policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few years it has become increasingly clear, and, I think, probably desirable, that career counselling of students is best done through the education system. There has been a considerable increase in the level of available career counselling in that system. Basically, that is designed to help students with questions of choice about future careers if, indeed, future careers be available to them. On the other hand, the Commonwealth Employment Service has provided some other services; it has provided career reference centres. There is one in each capital city and in a number of provincial cities. These centres provide a full range of printed, audio and other visual material about occupations and training courses which students might follow.

ANSWER.PARA: The services of the CES in this regard are widely publicised in schools and are used quite extensively. Work information centres have also been established in each office of the CES. They do not provide, perhaps, as comprehensive information as reference centres but they are more widely dispersed and available. Services are also provided by the CES to schools in terms of an occupational information library and training and on request assistance is provided to counsellors by the CES. The Government takes the view that an increasing amount of information should be made available to help young people with employment. That information, as a progressive measure, will increasingly be made available, both in schools and through the services of the CES.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, refers to the announcement by the Minister today that a judicial inquiry will be held into the Ivanov-Combe crisis and to his attempted explanation of why the Prime Minister did not mention such an inquiry yesterday. Is not the whole substance of yesterday's statement a clear implication by the Prime Minister that no inquiry and no further action would be taken and that, in the Prime Minister's words, the matter would be put to rest by that statement? If not, I ask the Minister to explain the meaning of the following paragraphs in the Prime Minister's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: It is perhaps inevitable that there will always be elements of doubt and suspicion in the minds of all Australians in circumstances where there can be less than full disclosure of information. That is a responsibility a Government must accept and for my part I accept it. But I trust this statement will put to rest the uncertainty of the last few days and convince all Australians of whatever political persuasion of the correctness and fairness of our handling of the matter.

I ask: Does this not indicate clearly that yesterday the Government had no intention at all of a judicial inquiry in the Combe affair as distinct from any thought that there might have been a judicial inquiry in the future into the structure of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me answer that question in this way: First of all, what I said earlier at Question Time was that the Prime Minister had taken steps a week or so ago to set in train a judicial inquiry. I might elaborate on what those steps were. I take it that the Prime Minister saw the most important question in relation to the establishment of a judicial inquiry as being the selection of an appropriate judge. That was the step that was taken a week or so ago, as far as I know. No other steps were taken, but that step was taken.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the honourable senator suggests that the implications of yesterday's statement by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives are that this matter should be put at rest in relation to Mr Combe. That statement was made in the context of full discussion with the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives from beginning to end regarding this matter. The Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives then allowed a series of questions from his own benches about this matter yesterday and there was discussion on a matter of public importance today in total conflict with the discussions which had taken place between the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister. It became quite apparent and it is quite apparent that this matter-because of attempts to obtain political advantage from it in this place-could not be put at rest by the statement that was made yesterday.That is the position which has affected the capacity to put this question at rest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Senator Button did not answer or attempt to answer the nub of my question; that is, the nature of the judicial inquiry sought about a week ago, whether the decision to include the Combe affair in a judicial inquiry was made before or after the statement yesterday and, incidentally, whether Mr Combe was in any way in possession of any knowledge that he was going to be involved in a judicial inquiry?

—The second part of the honourable senator's supplementary question has already been answered by Senator Evans. Insofar as the question relates to the nature of the judicial inquiry, it has already been said here in the Senate today that the terms of reference regarding that matter have not yet been determined and were not determined yesterday.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Large numbers of Australians now use bicycles as a preferred means of transport as well as for recreation. Does the Government intend to make provision in its Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program for the funding of bicycle tracks and routes, thereby contributing to health, safety and energy conservation?

—The honourable senator has asked a very interesting question. It is one which I believe should be considered in the context of our responsibilities in transport. I am aware of the fact that steps have been taken by many local government bodies, and indeed in the Australian Capital Territory, to provide bicycle tracks or paths. That is a matter which the Government would very strongly support, not only because it has some aspects of energy conservation, although I suppose one could argue that a different sort of energy is being expounded in the use of bicycles. I think there is a growing tendency in this country to use such bicycle tracks. It could be seen as part of a conservation policy in respect of petroleum products. It is an interesting observation and one which I will certainly refer to my colleague Mr Morris, whom I represent in this place, with some enthusiasm because I believe that in all developed and, indeed, developing areas such a proposal ought to be considered as part of providing an alternative mode of transport. Accordingly, I will refer the question not only to Mr Morris but also to Mr Uren, whom I also represent in this place.

—I also direct my question to the Attorney-General. It is about the proposed review of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, whether that be by way of a royal commission announced today or by way of whatever the Attorney-General was referring to yesterday. Does not the Attorney- General understand that if the Prime Minister of this country can condemn a citizen of Australia on the basis of information that he will not or cannot reveal, he, the Prime Minister, has destroyed civil liberties in this country and any review of our security forces is totally irrelevant?

—The honourable senator seems to have overlooked several key pieces of information which have been made abundantly clear in the course of discussions both yesterday and today. One is that there was a long period of discussion and consultation between the Government and Mr Combe before any statement was made by the Prime Minister. Secondly, Mr Combe agreed with the text of that statement. In the discussions he said that he understands and accepts the Government's position. If the honourable senator chooses to categorise the matter in the terms he used that is his prerogative but he does himself no credit in doing so.

—Yesterday Senator Martin asked me a question in respect of the Federal Government's attitude and commitment to the Brisbane City Council's bid for the 1987 World Student Games. I am now in a position to respond to Senator Martin. The Council has not made any formal approach to the Federal Government for assistance other than a request for the Prime Minister to provide a letter of support for the bid. This has been provided. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has had discussions with Alderman Harvey and representatives of the Council and he is aware of details of the Council's proposal. However, until such time as a decision is made on the location of the 1987 games it is not appropriate for the Government to enter into any comments in respect of them. Should Brisbane be awarded the games it would then be appropriate for the Council to determine its own financial arrangements and ascertain the level of Queensland Government assistance before it makes specific requests to the Federal Government. However, should it want to know before July whether the Federal Government will assist it should feel free to approach us, provided that the attitude of the Queensland Government is known at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question concerning funding of public transport services in Brisbane. I am now in a position to provide the following information: The development and operation of urban public transport services is primarily a matter for the States. As a consequence, the adequacy of the funding available to the Brisbane City Council for its bus operations is ultimately a matter for which the Queensland Government must take responsibility. The Commonwealth Government for its part recognises the important role which urban public transport can play in the movement of people in the cities. The States have the option whereby up to 25 per cent of the funds available for urban arterial roads under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program may be allocated to urban public transport capital projects where such projects will reduce traffic or wear and tear on urban road systems. It is therefore a matter for the States to determine, on the basis of their priorities, the urban public transport projects for which they seek funding under that program.

QUESTION.PARA: Earlier this year the Queensland Government sought and obtained from the then Minister for Transport and Construction approval for funding of two major projects involving extensive work to the Brisbane electrified rail network, as well as the construction of a number of smaller rail and bus passenger interchange projects. There is no question of the importance of the role played by the Brisbane City Council's bus services in meeting public transport requirements within the Brisbane area. In fact, figures suggest that Brisbane City Council buses account for about half of public transport passenger journeys in the Brisbane area. The honourable senator may therefore be assured that any proposals that may be submitted by the State relating to the upgrading of the Brisbane City Council bus services will receive careful and sympathetic consideration by the Commonwealth.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

PROCTEXT.PARA: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —To enable Estimates committees to meet, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Senate had an organised adjournment debate on the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Unfortunately, I had no knowledge that this debate was taking place.
—Shame!

—It appeared that some women senators had got together and chatted about this matter but what was discussed was not told to the rest of us and I was not aware that such a discussion was taking place. At the last minute, as the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, was concluding her speech, I did become aware of it. Before Senator Ryan leaves the chamber, I point out that I am addressing my remarks to her, and I would like a reply if possible.
—I will reply.

—I think Senator Ryan is in charge of this area but if she has passed on her responsibility to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes , that suits me fine. Last night I turned on the speaker in my room to hear Senator Ryan saying that all honourable senators were in agreement and that everything was sweetness and light. I assure her that that is not so. I read the record of the debate in Hansard. Senator Giles, who opened it, said that all reputable women's groups agreed. She then set out to attack one particular group of women, that named the Women Who Want to be Women. She seems to think-all Australian Labor Party people seem to think-that the worst thing they can say about any group is that they might be sheltered, wealthy women. I do not see what that has to do with it, but that seems to be the general way in which the Labor Party tries to denigrate people. Senator Giles went on to tell us that it is widely acknowledged that the League of Rights has some influence in this matter. I am not sure whether she was implying that the Women Who Want to be Women are also members of the League of Rights, but if she was it would be a good idea for her to claim that outside this place and not to use the Senate to make those inferences.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the speakers on the matter seemed to resort to using posters. Senator Giles said that she has in her room a poster showing an ordinary looking chap poised by a kitchen stove. It states: 'I am Joe average. My family means more to me than anything else. That is why I share the responsibility of the housework and caring for the kids'. He hasn't got to stand over a stove to prove his love for his family'. It seems to me to be rather pathetic. Senator Giles said that the Women Who Want to be Women claim that Australia will be placed under the control of foreign people if it signs the Convention. I do not believe that Australia will be placed under the control of foreign organisations, but they certainly have influence. Senator Giles pointed to the International Labour Organisation. She said that if foreign organisations had a great influence in Australia, it would have been the case with the ILO. I can assure her that is the case. What is the point of Australia ratifying any agreement with the ILO if it does not have some influence on government legislation? I assure her that it does. She has not been in Government for long. She probably is not aware that it does. Conventions certainly have an influence on government legislation, and no doubt she will learn that that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —World heritage.

—We will talk about the world heritage if Senator Coates wants to bring that matter on again. As I said last night, the Schedule to the World Heritage Convention states very clearly that a country that has a federation, as we have, and whose constitution does not allow it to take any action, just passes recommendations on to the States. That is where the World Heritage Convention has landed. I now refer to Senator Giles's remarks about Scandinavia. She is obviously a great lover of the Scandinavian people. She said that Scandinavian women no longer talk about equality but about equivalence. She suggested that the Women Who Want to be Women should claim their equivalence and join their sisters in supporting the Convention. I am not quite sure what she means by 'equivalence'. I wish she were here because I would be only too pleased to let her have a couple of seconds to tell us what she means by 'equivalence' in the context. She certainly did not explain it in her speech. I looked at the dictionary to check the meaning of 'equivalence'. It means interchangeable, equivalent, or exactly the same.
—It does not. Go back to first year maths.
—Go and look at the dictionary because you might learn something . 'Equivalence' means completely interchangeable.
—Order! I suggest the honourable senator address her remarks through the Chair.

—I assure Senator Giles that nature does not permit her to be interchangeable. No matter how much Senator Giles, Senator Ryan or Senator Haines would like it to be, nature does not permit that to happen. I now turn to Senator Haines's example. Senator Haines also resorted to the fact that she has a poster in her room. Her poster is different and it states: 'Anything a woman does she has to do twice as well as a man to be considered half as good. Fortunately that is not difficult'. For heaven's sake, that shows the depth of the debate in this place last night. It is rather ludicrous. Senator Haines then told us that she has brought up her two girls in such a free way that they say: 'Women drive better than men'. Good heavens, I have never heard anything so pathetic. She brought up her girls so freely that they say that women drive better than men. I brought up my girls quite a considerable time earlier than Senator Haines brought up hers. My girls have had complete equality with my boys in every single way. They have all gone through university; they have had every advantage. There has been no suggestion that they should resort to this idiotic nonsense of saying: 'We drive better than men'. They consider themselves to be equal with boys in every way and always have. They have been brought up that way . They do not have to resort to this trivial nonsense of saying: 'We have to work four times as hard as men to get acknowledgment', or 'Fortunately it is not very hard to work four times as hard as a man.' They have not been brought up in that stupid, idiotic fashion. They do not resort to saying such things as: ' Women drive better than men'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines then went on to say that if her daughters chose to take up parenting as a full time role it would suit her fine although she would not know from whom they got that inclination; it certainly would not be from her. Senator Haines went on to ridicule full time parenting by women. This is really what the group Women Who Want to be Women is all about. Their point has been made by Senator Haines's ridiculing of this very worthwhile job of women who decide to take up parenting as their only priority, as a full time role. There is no reason for these feminists to ridicule the job that many women-the majority of women-in Australia want to do. There is no need for the ridicule. Women have a choice of taking up parenting as a full time role, without being ridiculed, or of not having children, as the case may be. If they want to have children at least they cannot hand over that role to anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why can't men also have a choice?

—If Senator Coates wants to know why they cannot I will give him a biology lesson later. Women cannot hand over the role of giving birth to children, nor can they hand over the role of nurturing them straight after the birth. It seems to me to be a very sad situation when a female member of the Senate stands up and says that she would not encourage her girls to take up parenting as a full time role and she could not imagine from where they would get the inclination if they chose to do so. When Senator Ryan's Bill eventually comes before the Senate I will have more to say about this matter. I think Senator Giles put her view rather well when she said: 'The hysterical emphasis on the sanctity of the family and the well-being of children has been put abroad by the Women Who Want to be Women'. I do not believe that it is hysterical. In this country there is one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages. I think we should be looking very closely at what is happening to our families and to the children of those divorces. Mr President, I think it would be more appropriate for me to debate this matter when the Bill comes before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is my first opportunity since your election as President to congratulate you. It is the first time that you have been in the chair when I have spoken. I rise only very briefly to put the record straight on a couple of matters. I do not want to recanvass the subject of last night's debate. There was a suggestion early in Senator Walters' s speech that the adjournment debate last night was something on which a number of us had got together. I wish to explain that I have some responsibility for the Opposition on the subject. Whilst Mr Macphee is the shadow Minister responsible for the status of women I have a responsibility in the Senate to represent him in that portfolio. I indicated to Senator Ryan, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, that I wished to raise the issue of the ratification of the Convention at the appropriate time in the Senate. That appropriate occasion had not eventuated when I was informed by Senator Giles that she had approached Senator Ryan to raise the matter on the adjournment. Senator Ryan did me the courtesy of telling Senator Giles that I had indicated that it was a subject that I intended to raise. So, not unnaturally, we took the opportunity to speak on the matter at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing that I wanted to say is something that I omitted to say last night. It was our policy while in government to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. We were moving towards that eventuality. It is still the policy of the Opposition that the Convention be ratified. The anti-discrimination legislation has been mentioned in the Press today. I make no comment because we have not seen the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk on the same subject, having had the opportunity of reading a debate which occurred last evening relating to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women which is under discussion. I think the issues that were raised last night are extremely important. Earlier this week I met with the various people who were mentioned in Senator Martin's contribution to the debate last night; that is, Dr Rendle-Short, Mrs Jackie Butler and Mrs Robyn Sully. I met those people on Monday to discuss these matters. It was a robust and interesting meeting over some two and a half hours. I cannot say that we agreed on all that much, except possibly that it is a subject which ought to be a matter of debate in the community. I certainly support that. On items such as this where Australia is to ratify a convention I have always said that the broadest possible debate should take place and the larger the input which can be made to the ratification the better.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that if one looked at how these conventions operated in practice, the Government of the day, in terms of its own legislation, would use or not use those conventions as it sees fit in relation to its own legislation. But the conventions may have some worth in altering the perceptions of people one to another of how they might act and what might be the most appropriate way of acting.

The people who came to see me on Monday expressed a wide range of concerns and a range of specific concerns. I do not think I was able to allay any of their fears in relation to these items. However, I did not feel that the items which they raised with me warranted any action to prevent the ratification going ahead . I raise a further point that it seems to me that prior to these items being ratified there ought to be a major parliamentary debate. Indeed, I believe that the best way in which these ratifications could take place would be by a majority vote of both Houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did that of course in the Senate in October 1981.

—Right. I believe that that would then bring into the Parliament and into the general political debate the issues which are currently outside this chamber. Some of those matters were raised last night. But specific items such as concern about whether this Convention would trespass upon the rights of certain churches not to have women ministers is one which is of concern to a number of people. I do not believe that that is a valid concern. I believe that any reading of our Constitution would show that the Government is not capable of using the foreign affairs power to override another section of the Constitution. This makes it impossible for the Commonwealth to legislate in that area. But when we go through the Convention I think we need to pay attention to individual items because there is a lot of fear being raised in the community at the moment , as was mentioned last night. I believe their fears are genuine but unfounded. That is a matter for further input. I must say that I finally got to the point of wondering whether there was a capacity for rational debate in this area. That may have been a reaction to two and a half hours of discussion.
—On the male ego.

—On the male ego, possibly. That may not be the type of reaction that one ought to have in this area, and one should perhaps press on and hope that rational discussion may eventually prevail. No one would want us not to ratify the Convention because not to ratify it might be seen, not only in the world community but also in Australia, as this chamber and this Parliament not having a commitment to eliminating discrimination against women in all the forms it can take within society.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make one comment on an item raised by Senator Walters earlier on. I refer to Senator Haines's comments last night when she was wondering, I feel in her relatively well-known facetious way, from where her children may have got the idea that they wanted to take up parenting. I know both her children and I know that they have a sense of humour, which enables one to get a long way in the world. But Senator Walters then said that Senator Haines last night went on to denigrate the role of parenting. I will read the passage immediately after the one quoted by Senator Walters to show that that is not the case. Senator Walters quoted the following passage from Senator Haines's speech:
If they choose to take up parenting as a full time role that will suit me fine although I do not know where they would get the inclination from-certainly not from me.
The next sentence is:
Nevertheless, they will be entitled to do so.
The only denigration she undertook, in the next sentence, was upon our profession when she said:
If they want to pursue a career in politics of course I will try to dissuade them, but they are entitled to pursue any other area as far as I am concerned.

I wonder whether in the ensuing debate it may be possible to have less invective against personalities and possibly more substance, because I believe that in Australia in 1983 there is still a long way to go in this area. I do not agree with Senator Walters that women in Australia can do exactly what they want. She may very well have been able to do so. I strongly disagree that it is the experience of all women in Australia that they are able to do so. Indeed, there are very evident discriminations against women in many areas.

Finally, I believe that a discussion should take place about the notion of parenting rather than about whether it should be done by men or women. I believe that both males and females have a role in it. It is acknowledged now that it is an extremely important role which both fulfil. I think that in 1983 we as a chamber should seek to support and further that role which is under a great deal of pressure within our community. It does not necessarily follow from that support of the role of parenting, as far as we are able, that government must say in legislation that the role of women is in some way lesser than the role of men. Indeed, if one looks at the role that women fulfil in our society I think it can be seen that there is one area in which this comes out very strongly. I refer to migrant women, who are in extremely difficult circumstances in this country-particularly those migrant women who come from countries where English is not the language. They are often isolated from the rest of the community and find great difficulty in really developing themselves, and the roles which they may be capable of having, anywhere as much as I am sure they would like to. That is merely one area in which discrimination still exists. When we have a debate on this I hope that we will be able to discuss those items in a more reasonable and responsible way and that, flowing from that, legislation will be introduced here which will assist us to overcome the very real concerns and the very real discrimination which still exists against women in this country in 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing this adjournment debate I wish to make a couple of points. The first point is that I represent the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, because she has an engagement she cannot avoid. She knew that this matter was going to come up for debate today only a couple of minutes before the motion for the adjournment of the Senate was moved. I think it is unfortunate that Senator Walters, and by interjection Senator Lewis, made remarks about Senator Ryan's absence. It is particularly unfortunate when Senator Walters started the debate and then soon after making her contribution left the chamber, before hearing the contribution to the debate by any other honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the remarks of Senator Macklin that it is important that we have a wide-ranging and less emotional debate than we sometimes have on this and other subjects, particularly when we are talking about the ratification of conventions of this type. In regard to my own area of social security, I find Senator Walters's assertion today that women are equal in this community incredible. I think of how women are disproportionately represented amongst the poor, amongst the homeless and amongst the unemployed; how the levels of education which they reach are disproportionately lower than those of men; and how amongst the echelons of industry and the Public Service in this country they are also disproportionately represented. However, I think that is a matter for another time and another debate. I thank all honourable senators for their contributions . I wish that all contributions could be less emotional and less rhetorical and could contain less hyperbole than did Senator Walters's contribution, but I suppose that is a hope I will live with for a long time before I see it achieved .
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did an Australian Financial Review report of 14 April claim that clothing manufacturers are avoiding Customs duty.

(3) What has been the result of such investigations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) None. However, users of the by-law concession to which the article refers are required to furnish Customs securities and quarterly returns to ensure its purpose is complied with.
